==Stalemate (1–14 June)==
===1 June=== *NATO extended its mission to enforce U.N. Security Council Resolution 1973 for an additional ninety days.<ref>{{cite web | author = Press release |url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/news_74977.htm|title=Statement by the NATO Secretary General on the Extension of the Mission in Libya|date=1 June 2011|publisher= [[NATO]] |accessdate=25 August 2011}}</ref> The [[United Nations Human Rights Council|UN Human Rights Council]] declared that its fact-finding mission found Gaddafi guilty of [[war crime]]s and [[crimes against humanity]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/01/us-libya-un-crimes-idUSTRE7506IS20110601|title=U.N. Finds War Crimes by Gaddafi Forces, Opposition|agency=[[Reuters]] |date=1 June 2011|accessdate=25 August 2011}}</ref> *Ghanem defected from the Gaddafi administration due to "unbearable violence". Despite uncertainty at first over joining the opposition, he later declared his support to the NTC in a Roman news conference.<ref name="Ghanem">{{cite news|title=Libya Oil Chief Defects as NATO Extends Campaign|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/01/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110601|agency=[[Reuters]]|author1=Graff, Peter |author2=Babington, Deepa |date=1 June 2011|accessdate=25 August 2011}}</ref> *Rebel forces reported that [[Shakshuk]], near the city of [[Jadu, Libya|Jadu]] and well within Gaddafi territory, was captured.<ref name=Ghanem/> *Four car explosions triggered by a [[hand grenade]] damaged the [[Tibesti Hotel]] in Benghazi, a hotel used by the NTC and residence of many foreign journalists. Despite damage to the hotel, there were no injuries or casualties.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/02/us-libya-blast-idUSTRE7505T520110602|title=Blast Hits Hotel in Libya's Rebel-Held Benghazi|agency=[[Reuters]] | author =El Madany, Sherine|date=1 June 2011|accessdate=25 August 2011}}</ref>
===2 June=== *Cooling international concern, the Libyan opposition has downplayed concerns of oil contract re-negotiation as they meet with the leaders in Libya's oil industry.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/02/us-energy-libya-deals-idUSTRE75154220110602|title=Libya Rebels Are Not Revising Oil Deals: Source|agency= [[Reuters]] |author =El Madany, Sherine|date=2 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> *NATO air attacks destroyed ammunition and vehicles depots, a [[Surface-to-air missile|SAM]] launcher, and a radar installation in the capital.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/20116214531744425.html|title=Gaddafi To Send Representative to OPEC|work= [[Al Jazeera]] |date=2 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
===3 June=== *Two [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] [[AgustaWestland Apache|Apache]] helicopters attacked a radar site and an armed checkpoint near Brega, the next logical waypoint in the opposition's campaign westward. French [[Aérospatiale Gazelle|Gazelles]] were reported to have simultaneously been out on mission, marking the first time the helicopters were used by NATO.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13651736|title=Libya: UK Apache Helicopters Used in NATO Attacks|work=BBC News|date=4 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> *Opposition fighters reportedly liberated the western towns, Qasr el-Haj, Shakshuk, and Bir Ayyad of loyalist forces.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/20116341054115467.html|title=NATO Jets Target Libyan Capital|publisher=Al Jazeera |date=3 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/03/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110603|title=China Meets Libya Rebels in Latest Blow to Gaddafi|agency=[[Reuters]]|author =Graff, Peter|date=3 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
===4–5 June=== *[[Army Air Corps (United Kingdom)|Army Air Corps]] [[AH-64 Apache|Apache]] gunships, launched from the [[HMS Ocean (L12)|HMS ''Ocean'']], destroyed several targets near the Brega-Ajdabiya front line including ammunition bunkers and radar installations while the French Gazelles also hit numerous targets around Brega in preparation for the perceived upcoming rebel offensive on the ground.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jun/05/nato-libya-apache-gunships-success|title=NATO Strike Force in Libya Enjoys Quick Success with Apache Gunships|work=The Guardian |location=London | author =Sengupta, Kim |date=5 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/04/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110604|title=NATO Helicopters Ratchet Up Pressure on Gaddafi|agency= [[Reuters]]| author =Graff, Peter|date=4 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> *Libyan state media was under attack today because they told foreign reporters that a child who was injured in a NATO airstrike sustained her injuries in an unrelated car crash. This information was apparently passed to the foreign reporters in a note, at the hospital where she was situated.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/06/us-libya-casualty-idUSTRE75504A20110606|title=Gaddafi Aides Present Car Crash Baby as NATO Victim|agency=[[Reuters]] | author = Graff, Peter|date=5 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> *The Netherlands and Denmark denied recognition of the NTC as the authority of Libya after rebels claimed such.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nisnews.nl/public/060511_1.htm|title=Netherlands Denies Recognition of Rebels as Libyan Authority|work=NIS News Bulletin|date=5 June 2011|accessdate=15 June 2011}}</ref>
===6 June=== *The mountain town of Yafran, roughly {{convert|100|km|abbr=off}} southwest of Tripoli, was reported to be under opposition control. Nalut and Zintan were reported to be "relatively quiet" by the opposition, though independent verification of this had not yet been made possible.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/06/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110606|title=Libyan Rebels Seize Mountain Town|agency=[[Reuters]] | author = Youssef, Boudlal|date=6 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/20116613502238785.html|title=Rebels 'Wrest Town from Gaddafi Forces'|work= [[Al Jazeera]]|date=6 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> *Additionally, NATO airstrikes leveled the offices of Libyan State TV and Gaddafi's military intelligence in Tripoli, though Libyan state authorities claimed only the latter was destroyed. Areas under opposition control reported disruption of state TV broadcasts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-6-2011-2145-0|title= Libyan Live Blog: June 6, 2011 – 21:45|work= [[Al Jazeera]] |date=6 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> *In order to be knowledgeable of the terrain ahead, opposition forces in Misrata have been training men smuggled out of Zliten while coordinating their efforts with the city's tribal chiefs prior to launching any offensive westward.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.scotsman.com/news/Libya-Doubt-over-city39s-loyalty.6780209.jp?articlepage=1|title=Libya: Doubt Over City's Loyalty Puts Brake on Rebel Advance|work=The Scotsman |author =Sherock, Ruth |date=6 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011|location=Edinburgh, UK}}</ref>
===7 June=== *Gaddafi appeared live and vowed to stay in Libya "dead or alive" as NATO launched some of its most destructive airstrikes yet, targeting key loyalist military installations of the Libyan secret police, [[Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guard]] and Popular Guard.<ref name=AJ_strikes_607>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/20116791428754691.html|title=NATO Strikes Rock Libyan Capital|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=7 June 2011|accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=Reuters_strikes_607>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/07/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110607|title=Gaddafi Vows To Fight On, NATO Jets Pound Tripoli| agency= [[Reuters]]| author = Graff, Peter|date=7 June 2011|accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref> *Libyan Labour Minister, [[Al-Amin Manfur]], defected and joined the opposition at a meeting of the [[International Labour Organization]] in Geneva, Switzerland.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/08/world/africa/08tripoli.html|title=NATO Attack Destroys Much of Qaddafi Compound|work=The New York Times| author = [[Helene Cooper|Cooper, Helene]] |date=7 June 2011|accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref> *There are some reports that one of Gaddafi's sons, [[Mutassim Gaddafi]], was killed in an airstrike that was conducted by NATO.<ref name="allvoices.com">{{cite news|last=Devlin|first=Michelle|date=7 June 2011|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/9329031-mutassim-gaddafi-is-dead-killed-in-brega-by-nato-airstrike|title=Mutassim Gaddafi Is Dead: Killed in Brega by NATO airstrike|work=AllVoices|accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref> *It was reported on 7 June that Abu-Bakr Yunis Jabr was executed by Gaddafi for refusing to carry out orders to kill protesters. It might be true since Abu-Bakr Yunis Jabr had not appeared on national Libyan television, and there had been no outside communication with him.<ref name="allvoices.com"/>
===8 June=== *Loyalist forces took advantage of a break in heavy airstrikes to launch a large attack on Misrata as well as Zintan, but did not make any gains.<ref name=AJ_Misrata_608>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/201168151339758908.html|title=Gaddafi Forces Shell Rebel-Held Misurata|publisher=Al Jazeera |date=8 June 2011|accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref> *Spain announced its designation of the NTC as the sole legitimate government of Libya.<ref name=AJ_Misrata_608/> *As [[International Criminal Court]] judges debated issuing arrest warrants for Gaddafi and his confederates, the organization's [[Luis Moreno Ocampo|chief prosecutor]] announced that it had received reliable reports that the Gaddafi administration was buying large quantities of "[[sildenafil|Viagra]]-[[PDE5 inhibitor|type]] drugs" in order to encourage soldiers to [[war rape|rape]] supporters of the opposition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/201168223922140673.html|title=Fresh NATO Airstrikes Rock Tripoli|work= [[Al Jazeera]] |date=9 June 2011|accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref>
===9 June=== *Nations supporting the opposition agreed to finance the NTC with over $1.1 billion USD as the rebel finance minister announced plans to gradually restore oil exports in the west.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/09/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110609|title= Libya Rebels Win Aid as West Sees Gaddafi Exit|agency= [[Reuters]] |last1=Graff|first1=Peter|last2=Pamuk|first2=Humeyra |date=9 June 2011|accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref> *The US and Australia recognized the NTC as the legitimate interlocutor of Libya, one step below formal diplomatic recognition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304259304576375593529584086.html|title=US, Allies Eye Post-Gadhafi Libya|work=The Wall Street Journal | author = Malas, Nour|date=10 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011}}</ref> *Opposition forces claimed that over a dozen of Gaddafi's high-ranking military officials defected while rebels in the key mountain city of Zintan attempted to establish control.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/06/09/libya.war/|title=International Powers Boost Support for Libyan Rebels|work = [[CNN]] | date=9 June 2011|accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref>
===10 June=== *The African Union chairperson participated as Invitee in the third meeting of the International Contact Group on Libya.<ref>{{cite press release|date=10 June 2011|url=http://www.au.int/en/sites/default/files/10%2006%2011_Chairperson_Ping_Holds_important_consultations_on_Libya_in_AbuDhabi-1.pdf |title=Chairperson Participates as Invitee, in the Third Meeting of the International Contact Group on Libya|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|publisher=[[African Union]]|accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref> *The African Union called for Gaddafi to step down as [[Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz]], the leader of the AU Libya mediation team announced that Gaddafi "can no longer lead Libya."<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.au.int/en/sites/default/files/FINAL_Communique_Third_Meeting_of_the_International_Contact_Group_on_Libya_June_9_20111.pdf|publisher=African Union|format= [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |title=Third Meeting of the International Contact Group on Libya Abu Dhabi Communiqué|date=10 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011}}</ref> *Misrata continued to be bombarded by loyalist forces while clashes between Gaddafi's forces and rebel fighters erupted in the neighboring Zliten. [[Ghadames]], an [[oasis]] town bordering Tunisia, was shelled by loyalist forces for the first time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/10/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110610|title=Fighting Erupts in Zlitan, Turkey Offers Gaddafi Exit|agency=[[Reuters]]| author =El Madany, Sherine|date=10 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011}}</ref> *The leader of a UN inquiry into [[international human rights law|human rights]] violations in Libya expressed his skepticism over any official rape policy by the Gaddafi administration. He cited that alleged statistical evidence was never received by officials and that the allegations were a result of "mass hysteria". The allegations were based on surveys supposedly delivered through the postal system, but it was inoperable during the period it was claimed to have been used. Both loyalist and opposition parties accuse one another of committing war crimes according to the investigation. However, a [[Margot Wallström|senior U.N. official]] defended the validity of the claim, citing "consistent reports from people, from organisations, from UN entities and others on the ground."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/libya-rape-claims-hysteria-investigator/story-e6frf7jx-1226072781882|title=Libya Rape Claims 'Hysteria' – Investigator|work=Herald Sun |location=Australia|date=10 June 2011|accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.expatica.com/ch/news/swiss-news/un-official-investigator-at-odds-over-libya-mass-rape-claim_155646.html|title=UN official, Investigator at Odds over Libya Mass Rape Claim|work= [[Expatica]]|date=10 June 2011|accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref>
===11 June=== *Rebels in [[Zawiya, Libya|Zawiya]], a city just {{convert|50|km|abbr=off}} from Tripoli, won control of some sections, marking the first significant clashes between loyalist and opposition forces since [[First Battle of Zawiya|it was recaptured]] by Gaddafi's troops in March. Due to the ongoing fighting, loyalist forces closed down a highway that crosses the town, a key expressway for Gaddafi's war effort.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/11/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110611|title=Fighting in Zawiyah Shuts Libya Road to Tripoli|agency= [[Reuters]] | author =Graff, Peter|date=11 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011}}</ref> A spokesman for the NTC explained that many of the rebels that fled Zawiya during its fall to Gaddafi in March had been training in the mountains in preparation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/libyan-rebels-battle-for-key-oil-port-near-tripoli/2011/06/11/AGwUcoQH_story.html|title=Libyan Rebels Battle for Key Oil Port Near Tripoli|work=The Washington Post| author =Londono, Ernesto|date=11 June 2011|accessdate=12 June 2011}}</ref> *Rebels reported that two of [[Muammar Gaddafi#Personal life and family|Gaddafi's sons]] were in command of the loyalist offensive at Zliten–Misrata front. One of these is [[Khamis Gaddafi]], commander of the [[Khamis Brigade]], a [[special forces]] brigade loyal exclusively to Gaddafi and reportedly one of the few loyalist brigades still intact. A day earlier he had been quoted telling his troops, "Take Misurata or I will kill you myself. If you don't take Misrata, we are finished."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/libyan-rebels-stage-insurrection-in-zlitan/2011/06/10/AGpi44OH_story.html#NATO|work=The Washington Post|title=Libyan Rebels Stage Unsurrection in Zlitan| author =Denyar, Simon|date=10 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011}}</ref>
===12 June=== *A government spokesman alleged that the rebels were defeated in Zawiya after hours of fighting.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE75B0D720110612|title=Libyan Government Says Zawiyah Revolt Defeated|work=Reuters Africa|agency = [[Reuters]] |author =Lowe, Christian|date=12 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref> A group of foreign reporters were taken from Tripoli to Zawiya for confirmation of the loyalist victory. The reporters confirmed that fighting had ceased throughout the areas they toured though they did not enter the western portion. Only hours earlier, rebels claimed to have surrounded loyalists in the west at three sides. The government further alleged that opposition forces had been pushed out of the city and surrounded on the edge of Zawiya. Reporters were unable to independently verify this, however.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43370270/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa|title=Libya's Rebels Claim Resurgence; Government Denies|agency =[[Associated Press]]|work=[[MSNBC]]|author1=Al-Shalchi, Hadeel |author2=Michael, Maggie |date=12 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref> This was potentially confirmed when a reporter heard several gunshots west of the city center and a rebel fighter in the town stating that fighting was still taking place.<ref name="Rt_Zawiya_612">{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/12/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110612|title=Libyan Rebels Say Still Fighting Near Capital|agency =[[Reuters]] |author =Carey, Nick|date=12 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/12/us-libya-zawiyah-idUSTRE75B2HJ20110612|title=Zawiyah's Heart a Ghost Town After Rebel Advance| agency= [[Reuters]] | author = Carey, Nick|date=12 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref> *A force of 130 rebels attempted to advance on Brega but were repelled and pulled back to Ajdabiya. At least 25 of the opposition fighters were killed and 65 wounded during the offensive, with a rebel commander later claiming many casualties were suffered when loyalist troops feigned a surrender under a [[white flag]], then fired on rebel soldiers as they approached.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/13/us-libya-brega-idUSTRE75C00K20110613|title=Gaddafi Forces Repel Rebels at Libyan Oil Town| agency = [[Reuters]] | author = Golovnina, Maria|date=12 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/2011613165648361721.html|title=Libyan Rebel Fighters Suffer Losses| work = [[Al Jazeera]]|date=13 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref> *Loyalist forces shelled Zintan from a distance as it remained under rebel control.<ref name=AJ_Zabiya_612>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/2011612155350821500.html|title=Rebels Battle Gaddafi Forces in Western Libya| work = [[Al Jazeera]] |date=12 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref> *The United Arab Emirates announced its full diplomatic recognition of the NTC as the legitimate government of Libya.<ref name="Rt_Zawiya_612"/>
===13 June=== *German [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Germany)|Foreign Minister]] [[Guido Westerwelle]] announced that the NTC was "the legitimate representative of the Libyan people," but it was not a full diplomatic recognition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-06/13/c_13927209.htm|title=Germany Recognizes Libyan Opposition NTC as Legitimate Representative|publisher=Xinhua News Agency|date=13 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702303714704576383962606983234.html?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Germany Acknowledges Libyan Rebels|work=The Wall Street Journal|author1=Crawford, David |author2=Parkinson, Joe |date=14 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref> *Contact with the rebel spokesman in Zawiya, who was updating journalists on the fighting there, had ceased and the highway running through Zawiya toward the Tunisian border was re-opened, indicating that the fighting had stopped and the earlier reports of a rebel defeat were true. Foreign journalists were taken on a tour along the highway, confirming that traffic wasn't being re-routed anymore around Zawiya, as was done at the beginning of the battle.<ref name="reuters1">{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/13/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110613?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews|title=Germany Recognizes Libya's Rebel Leadership|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=15 June 2011|date=13 June 2011}}</ref> *Libyan rebel forces advanced from Misrata to within ten kilometers of the neighboring city of Zliten, {{convert|160|km|abbr=off}} east of Tripoli.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/africa/articles/2011/06/14/libyan_rebels_crack_siege_move_toward_tripoli| agency = [[Associated Press]]|work=The Boston Globe|title=Libyan Rebels Crack Siege, Move Toward Tripoli|author1=Al-Shalchi, Hadeel |author2=Michael, Maggie |date=14 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=Rt_gains_614>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE74E1I420110614|title=Libyan Rebels Make Fresh Gains, NATO Drops Leaflets| work=Reuters Africa|agency=[[Reuters]]|author1=Boudlal, Youssef |author2=Robinson, Matt |date=14 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref> *Loyalist troops launched six missile attacks on an [[oil refinery]] in Misrata, though the oil storing facilities were reported to not have been damaged.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2011/06/14/51669473.html|title=Gaddafi Troops Launch Missile Attack on Misrata Refinery|agency = [[Associated Press]]|work=[[Voice of Russia]]|date=14 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref>
==Rebel push towards Tripoli (14 June – 15 August)==
===14 June=== *Loyalist forces fired several Grad rockets which landed within the Tunisian border. No injuries or damage were reported, and it was not immediately clear why this occurred.<ref name=AA_gains_614>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/06/14/153243.html|title=Libyan Rockets Fired into Tunisia as Rebels 'Tricked' by Qaddafi Troops and US Urges Africa| work = [[Al Arabiya]] | author = Tayel, Abeer|date=14 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011}}</ref> *Rebel fighters expelled Gaddafi troops from the town of [[Kikla]], {{convert|150|km|abbr=off}} southwest of Tripoli, and immediately began fortifying their positions. Later reports announced that the opposition had seized the town of Ryayna, {{convert|15|km|abbr=off}} of Zintan. Rebels based in Misrata managed to move the front lines several kilometers west, closer to Zliten, after fierce fighting. Despite a renewed rebel offensive towards Brega, negligible progress was made on the eastern front.<ref name=Rt_gains_614/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/15/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110615|title=Libyan Rebels Take New Villages in Western Mountains|agency = [[Reuters]]|author=Carey, Nick|date=14 June 2011|accessdate=6 January 2013}}</ref> *Canada recognized the NTC as Libya's sole legitimate government while Liberia announced it was cutting formal diplomatic relations with the Gaddafi administration.<ref name=Rt_gains_614/><ref name=AA_gains_614/> *The [[United States House of Representatives|US House of Representatives]] approved an amendment blocking additional funding for its military operations in Libya, effectively limiting the length of time US forces can continue their operation to two more months, without [[War Powers Resolution|US Congressional approval of war]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/20116147535393778.html|title=US House Votes To Block Funding for Libya|work = [[Al Jazeera]]|date=14 June 2011|accessdate=15 June 2011}}</ref>
===15 June=== *NATO jets resumed airstrikes on the capital overnight, bombarding it primarily in the east. Additionally, a NATO commander confirmed that warplanes bombed an ammunition store at [[Waddan, Libya|Waddan]] in the center of the country.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/15/ozatp-libya-idAFJOE75E02K20110615 Carey, Nick, and Youssef Boudlal, "NATO strikes Tripoli, Libyan Rebels Make Gains," Reuters, 15 June 2011, 1:14 a.m. EDT]</ref> *Tunisia announced it was ready to recognize the rebels as Libya's sole legitimate government. It gave three reasons for this action: that the shelling of its own people rendered Gaddafi's government illegitimate, that it still resented Gaddafi's support to [[President of Tunisia|Tunisian President]] [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] during the ongoing [[Tunisian revolution]] which started in December 2010, and that Gaddafi's shelling of its territory had rendered its previous strategy of neutrality ineffective.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/06/15/tunisia-says-ready-to-recognise-libya-rebels.html|title=Tunisia Says Ready To Recognise Libya Rebels|date=15 June 2011|work = [[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]}}</ref> *The UN Security Council had its 6,555th meeting and the situation in Libya was discussed. The meeting did not result in any decisions, since the council heard the statement made by the African Union Ad Hoc High-Level Committee on Libya.<ref>{{cite press release|title=African Union will never hide from responsibilities in resolving Libyan conflict|publisher=United Nations|url=http://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2011/sc10280.doc.htm|date=16 June 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref>
===17 June=== *Rebels rejected Gaddafi's proposal to hold elections in three months.<ref>{{cite news|date=17 June 2011|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2011/6/17/headlines#1|title=U.S., Rebels Reject Gaddafi Proposal|work=[[Democracy Now!]]|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> *The [[Parliament of Sweden|Swedish Parliament]] withdrew three fighter jets and sent marines to Libya. Sweden extended participation in the NATO Libya mission.<ref>{{cite news|date=17 June 2011|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1646090.php/Sweden-extends-participation-in-NATO-Libya-mission|title=Sweden Extends Participation in NATO Libya Mission|agency=[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]]|work=[[Monsters and Critics]]|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> *Italy signed an accord with the head of Libya's interim rebel government on Friday to jointly tackle a migration crisis triggered by the violence.<ref>{{cite news|date=17 June 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-17-2011-1905|title=Libya Live Blog: Friday, June 17, 2011 – 19:05|agency=[[Reuters]]|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
===18 June=== *NATO said Libya was using mosques as shields.<ref>{{cite news|date=18 June 2011|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13823947|title=Nato Says Libya Uses Mosques as Shields|work=BBC News|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
===19 June=== *At least five people died in a NATO air strike that hit a house in Tripoli, Libyan government officials said.<ref>{{cite news|date=19 June 2011|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13826976?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter|title=Nato Raid Kills Five Civilians, Libyan Officials Say|work=BBC News|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> *NATO admitted that it accidentally hit a civilian neighborhood in an airstrike.<ref>{{cite news|date=19 June 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43454221/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/|title=NATO Cites Errant Missile in Libya Civilian Deaths|work=[[MSNBC]]|accessdate=18 August 2011|location=Tripoli}}</ref> *Citing multiple sources, CNN reported that several anti-Gaddafi protests took place in Tripoli on 17 June, with protesters numbering in the hundreds. Pro-Gaddafi forces opened fire on the protesters with live ammunition, resulting in three deaths.<ref>{{cite news|last=McKenzie|first=David|date=20 June 2011|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/06/19/libya.voices/index.html|title=What's Really Going On in Gadhafi's Tripoli?|publisher=CNN|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
===20 June=== *Rebels claimed to have cut off the supply of crude oil to Zawiya from the Awbari oil field at Rayayna.<ref>{{cite news|date=20 June 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-20-2011-2320|title=Libya Live Blog: Monday, June 20, 2011 – 22:20|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> *The [[European Union]] toughened its sanctions on Gaddafi's government by adding six port authorities controlled by Gaddafi's forces to its asset-freeze list, stating that Gaddafi "had lost all legitimacy to remain in power".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/06/20/eu-foreign-ministers-freeze-assets-libyan-ports/|title=EU Foreign Ministers Freeze Assets of Libyan Ports|agency= [[Associated Press]]|publisher=Fox News |date=20 June 2011|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> *Gaddafi government officials claimed that NATO killed 19 civilians in the town of [[Sorman]], {{convert|70|km|abbr=off}} west of Tripoli. This came only a day after NATO admitted to accidentally killing civilians in a separate airstrike in Tripoli.<ref>{{cite news|date=21 June 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-21-2011-0447|title=Libya Live Blog: Tuesday, June 21, 2011 – 04:47|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> NATO stated that the target in Surman was a military command and control node.<ref>{{cite press release|date=20 June 2011|url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/news_75647.htm|title=NATO Strikes Military Command and Control Node|publisher=[[NATO]]|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
===21 June=== *An unmanned NATO [[Northrop Grumman MQ-8 Fire Scout|MQ-8]] helicopter drone crashed due to enemy fire near Zliten while conducting reconnaissance.<ref name="Libya conflict: Nato loses drone helicopter">{{cite news| title=Libya Conflict: Nato Loses Drone Helicopter|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13858200|work=BBC News|date=21 June 2011|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
===23 June=== *Advancing rebels in the Nafusa Mountains discovered supplies left behind by the fleeing Gaddafi troops, which included Turkish humanitarian food rations which were discovered to have been manufactured in a factory in Turkey after the UN sanctions were in place, casting doubt on Turkey's commitment to the mission. The rations were first found in Shakshuk and then at three other former Gaddafi strongholds.<ref name=doubtTurkey>{{cite news| date = 23 June 2011 | url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-23-2011-1924|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Thursday, June 23, 2011 – 19:24| work = [[Al Jazeera]] | accessdate =18 August 2011}}</ref> * [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Brazilian External Relations Minister]] [[Antonio Patriota]] condemned the ostensible usage of antipersonnel mines by government forces in civilian areas. This was related to the discovery and deadly effect of Brazilian-made land mines upon rebel troops and civilians, even though Brazil, a party to the 1997 [[Ottawa Treaty]], had not legally manufactured or exported antipersonnel land mines since 1989.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/07/08/libya-government-lays-more-mines-western-mountains|title=Libya: Government Lays More Mines in Western Mountains|work=Human Rights Watch|date=8 July 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|location=Zintan}}</ref>
===24 June=== *More Libyan soldiers and police officers fled to Tunis by using boats.<ref>{{cite news|date=24 June 2011|url=http://www.hs.fi/ulkomaat/artikkeli/Libyalaisia+sotilaita+pakenee+veneill%C3%A4+Tunisiaan/1135267200511?ref=rss|title=Libyalaisia sotilaita pakenee veneillä Tunisiaan|language=Finnish|work=Helsingin Sanomat|accessdate=17 August 2011|agency=Reuters|location=Tunis|trans_title=Libyan soldiers to flee by boat to Tunisia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=24 June 2011|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/06/24/libya-defections-idUKLDE75N0JR20110624|title=Libyan Officers Flee by Boat to Tunisia – Report|work=Reuters UK|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref> *Turkey denied the allegations that it had sent rations to Gaddafi, as did the company whose label was found on the ration packages.<ref>{{cite news | date = 24 June 2011 | url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-24-2011-0049|title= ''Libya LIve Blog'': Friday, June 24, 2011 – 00:49|work = [[Al Jazeera]] | accessdate =17 August 2011}}</ref><ref name=UNIFOdenial>{{cite news| date = 24 June 2011 | url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-24-2011-1200|work= [[Al Jazeera]] |title=''Libya Live Blog'': Friday, June 24, 2011  – 12:00 | accessdate =17 August 2011}}</ref> The latter suggested that the food may have ended up in the hands of the Libyan government without the company's (UNIFO) knowledge; it furthermore stated that food was "not military" in nature.<ref name=UNIFOdenial/>
===25 June=== *Human-rights organisations cast doubt on claims of mass rape and other abuses perpetrated by forces loyal to Gaddafi, which had been widely used to justify NATO's war in Libya. NATO leaders, opposition groups and the media had produced a stream of stories since 15 February claiming the Gaddafi government had ordered mass rapes, used foreign mercenaries and employed helicopters against civilian protesters. An investigation by [[Amnesty International]] failed to find evidence for these human-rights violations and in many cases discredited or cast doubt on them. It also found indications that on several occasions Benghazi rebels appeared to have knowingly made false claims or manufactured evidence. Liesel Gerntholtz, the head of women's rights at [[Human Rights Watch]], which also investigated the charge of mass rape, said: "We have not been able to find evidence."<ref name="nzherald">{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/libya/news/article.cfm?l_id=467&objectid=10734384|date=25 June 2011|accessdate=25 July 2011|last=Cockburn|first=Patrick|title=Amnesty Questions Libyan Mass Rape | work = [[The New Zealand Herald]]}}</ref> *Rebels have repeatedly charged that mercenary troops from [[Central Africa|Central]] and West Africa had been used against them. Amnesty International found there was no evidence for this. "Those shown to journalists as foreign mercenaries were later quietly released," said Donatella Rovera, senior crisis response adviser for Amnesty, who was in Libya for three months after the start of the uprising. "Most were sub-Saharan migrants working in Libya without documents." Others were not so lucky and were lynched or executed. Rovera found two bodies of migrants in the Benghazi morgue and others were dumped on the outskirts of the city.<ref name="nzherald"/> *Amnesty International also stated that there was no proof of mass killing of civilians in Libya, which was the basis for NATO's military intervention. Most of the fighting during the first days of the uprising was in Benghazi, where 100 to 110 people were killed, and the city of [[Bayda, Libya|Bayda]], where 59 to 64 were killed, said Amnesty International. Most of these were probably protesters, though some may have obtained weapons. There was no evidence that aircraft or heavy anti-aircraft machine guns were used against crowds. Spent cartridges picked up after protesters were shot at came from Kalashnikovs or similar calibre weapons. The Amnesty International findings confirmed a report by the authoritative [[International Crisis Group]], which found that although the government had a history of brutal repression, there was no question of genocide. It added that "much Western media coverage has from the outset presented a very one-sided view of the logic of events, portraying the protest movement as entirely peaceful and repeatedly suggesting the regime's security forces were unaccountably massacring unarmed demonstrators who presented no security challenge".<ref name="nzherald"/>
===26 June=== *African leaders met in [[Pretoria]], South Africa, to try to come up with a peace proposal.<ref>{{cite news|date=26 June 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-26-2011-1713|title=Libya Live Blog: Sunday, June 26, 2011 – 17:13|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref> No representatives of the Gaddafi government or of the opposition were present at the talks because the opposition held that Gaddafi must give up his seat before they would take part in any negotiations.<ref>{{cite news|date=26 June 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-26-2011-1803|title=Libya Live Blog: Sunday, June 26, 2011 – 18:03|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref> *Opposition troops were believed to have advanced to just north of [[Bir Ayad]] near [[Bir al-Ghanam]] which is {{convert|52|km|abbr=off}} south of Zawiya, a western gateway to Tripoli.<ref>{{cite news|date=27 June 2011|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13921665|title=Libya: Fierce Fighting South-West of Tripoli|work=BBC News|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref>
===27 June=== *The [[International Criminal Court]] in [[The Hague]], Netherlands, issued an arrest warrant for Gaddafi, his son [[Saif al-Islam]] and his head of intelligence. It was only the second time in the court's history that it had issued an arrest warrant for a sitting head of state.<ref>{{cite news|date=28 June 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/20116278148166670.html|title=ICC Issues Gaddafi Arrest Warrant|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref>
===28 June=== *Rebels raided a loyalist army base at El Ga'a after it was hit by a NATO bomb. They captured ammunition and other equipment.<ref>{{cite news|date=28 June 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jun-28-2011-1804|title=Libya Live Blog: Tuesday, June 28, 2011 – 18:04|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/29/world/africa/29libya.html?ref=world|work=The New York Times|title=Libyan Base Falls to a Rebel Raid in the West|date=28 June 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|first=Kareem|last=Fahim|location=El Ga'a}}</ref> *Both Croatia and Bulgaria recognized the NTC as a legitimate representative of the Libyan people.<ref>{{cite news|last=Iliev|first=Nick|date=28 June 2011|url=http://www.sofiaecho.com/2011/06/28/1113888_bulgaria-and-croatia-recognise-libyas-transitional-national-council|title=Bulgaria and Croatia Recognise Libya's Transitional National Council|work=[[The Sofia Echo]]|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref>
===29 June=== *The French military confirmed that it had air dropped weapons in June to Libyan rebels fighting in the highlands south of Tripoli, in violation of the UN arms embargo. While key NATO allies were arguing the need to protect civilians set out in UN Resolution 1973 overrides this, the French military was facing criticism for overstepping the resolution, especially from the African Union and Russia.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news|date=29 June 2011|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13955751|title=Libya Conflict: France Air-Dropped Arms to Rebels|work=BBC News|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Abu-Aun|first=Lufti|date=30 June 2011|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/30/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110630|title=Russia: Arming Libya Rebels Is 'Crude Violation'|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref>
===30 June=== *British Foreign Secretary William Hague said the UK was offering 5,000 sets of body armor, 6,650 uniforms, 5,000 high-visibility vests and communications equipment to help police protect rebel leaders and international officials.<ref>{{cite news|date=29 June 2011|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=13956407|title=UK Sends Body Armor, Police Uniforms to Libya|accessdate=25 January 2012|work=ABC News|agency=Associated Press|first=Jamey|last=Keaten|location=London}}</ref> *The [[Politics of the Czech Republic|Czech Republic government]] recognized the NTC as the sole legitimate representative of the Libyan people, and delivered aid to Libyan hospitals.<ref>{{cite news|date=30 June 2011|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7425857.html|title=Czech Republic Recognizes Libya's NTC, Hands Over Aid|agency= [[Xinhua News Agency]]|work=People's Daily|accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref>
===Early July (1–15 July)===
===1 July=== *Libyan rebels came close to [[Bir al-Ghanam]], but retreated after being met with rocket fire.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8610236/Libyan-rebels-prepare-for-battle-50-miles-from-Tripoli.html|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |title=Libyan Rebels Prepare for Battle 50 Miles from Tripoli|date=1 July 2011|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Mili|first=Anis|title=Rockets Push Back Rebels South of Libyan Capital|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/01/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110701|accessdate=1 July 2011|agency= [[Reuters]]|date=1 July 2011}}</ref> *[[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]], Gaddafi's son, claimed that NATO had offered the government an "under the table" deal that would see the international arrest warrants against both men dropped.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jul/01/gaddafi-son-nato-libya-deal|title=Gaddafi's Son Claims NATO Wants Deal with Libya|work=The Guardian |location=London |date=1 July 2011|accessdate=1 July 2011|first=David|last=Smith}}</ref> *In an exclusive interview with [[RT (TV network)|RT]], Saif Gaddafi denied that he or anyone ordered killings of demonstrators in the early days of the uprising. He said that soldiers acted in self-defense as they were attacked by mobs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gaddafi's Son: Libya Like McDonald's for NATO – Fast War as Fast Food|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RpMugPQC4ZY| work = [[RT (TV network)|RT]] (via YouTube) |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> *Gaddafi warned Western allies that bombing of houses and offices in Europe would be a "legitimate target" since those are targeted in Libya. Gaddafi's taped message was broadcast to tens of thousands of supporters gathered in [[Martyrs' Square, Tripoli|Green Square]] in Tripoli.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14003423l|work=BBC News |title=Libya: Air Raid on Gaddafi Military Camp|date=2 July 2011|accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref> This was one of the biggest demonstrations in recent months, as thousands of Gaddafi supporters gathered in Tripoli's main square to show that the Libyan leader still boasted serious support from his people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rt.com/news/african-union-gaddafi-arrest/|title=Gaddafi Threatens To Switch War to NATO's Home Territory|work= [[RT (TV network)|RT]] |date=2 July 2011|accessdate=3 July 2011}}</ref>
===2 July=== *''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that the [[Sudan People's Armed Forces]] seized the southern Libyan town of [[Kufra]].<ref>{{cite news|last=McElroy|first=Damien|date=1 July 2011|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8611199/Sudanese-army-seizes-southern-Libyan-town.html|title=Sudanese Army Seizes Southern Libyan Town|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref> Sudanese officials denied this.<ref>{{cite news|date=3 July 2011|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/Sudan-repudiates-reports-on,39419 |title=Sudan Repudiates Reports on Occupying Libyan Town|work=[[Sudan Tribune]]|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref> *The African Union called for Gaddafi to stay out of Libya talks to end the conflict.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wild|first=Franz|date=1 July 2011|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-01/african-union-calls-for-qaddafi-to-stay-out-of-libya-talks-to-end-conflict.html|title=African Union Calls for Qaddafi To Stay Out of Libya Talks To End Conflict|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref> *Heavy shelling fell on Misrata and [[Dafniya]], where fighting wounded eleven rebels.<ref>{{cite news|date=3 July 2011|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/07/02/libya.war/|title=Libyan Rebels, Gadhafi Forces Exchange Fire; 11 Rebels Wounded|publisher=CNN|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref> *NATO confirms it has been ramping up its airstrikes on military targets in western Libya in recent days, bombing Tripoli and [[Gharyan]], a city about {{convert|113|km|abbr=on}} south of Tripoli, and armored vehicles in Bir al-Ghanam.<ref>{{cite news |last= Schreck|first=Adam | title = NATO Boosts Airstrikes on Military Targets in Libya |work=The Boston Globe|agency=Associated Press|location=Tripoli| date = 3 July 2011| url = http://www.boston.com/news/world/africa/articles/2011/07/03/nato_boosts_airstrikes_on_military_targets_in_libya/ | accessdate =3 July 2011 }}</ref>
===3 July=== *Libya rebels braced for a new push to Tripoli.<ref>{{cite news|date=3 July 2011|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7427596.html|title=Libya Rebels Brace for New Push to Tripoli|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|work=People's Daily|accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref>
===5 July=== *Pro-Gaddafi troops stated that they have captured a shipment of Qatari weapons that were headed to rebels by boat.<ref>{{cite news|date=5 July 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/07/2011755223504921.html|title=Gaddafi Forces 'Intercept Arms from Qatar'|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref> *NTC Minister of Defence [[Jalal al-Digheily]] reportedly met with the [[Qatar Armed Forces]] chief of staff in [[Doha]], Qatar.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=445264&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16| work = [[Gulf Times]] |date=6 July 2011|accessdate=6 August 2011|title=Armed Forces Chief Holds Talks}}</ref>
===6 July=== *Rebel fighters took the village of Al-Qawalish which is about {{convert|90|km|abbr=off}} south of Tripoli. That brought the opposition to within {{convert|30|km|abbr=off}} from [[Gharyan]], the strategic garrison town of held by Gaddafi's troops and which dominates the main North-South road between Tripoli and the Sahara desert. The rebels claimed that Gaddafi was storing weapons in the Sahara desert and recruiting fighters from neighbouring countries there.<ref>{{cite news|last=Doyle|first=Mark|date=7 July 2011|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14074069|title=Libya Rebels Make Most Significant Advance in the West|work=BBC News|accessdate=8 July 2011}}</ref>
===7 July=== *[[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Russian Foreign Minister]] [[Sergey Lavrov]] said there cannot be a quick outcome in Libya and that will lead to many casualties on both sides. Lavrov said NATO put itself in a difficult situation because it has already been bombing Libya longer than it bombed what was [[Serbia and Montenegro|Yugoslavia]]. Lavrov called NATO's actions in Libya cynical, because the alliance continues bombings, claiming they were aimed at ending Gaddafi's government and ignoring the fact that they have already taken many civilian lives.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rt.com/news/lavrov-uk-regime-british/|title=No Quick Solution to Libyan Conflict – Lavrov|work= [[RT (TV network)|RT]] |date=7 July 2011|accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref> * Chinese diplomat Chen Xiaodong, in charge of North African affairs at the Foreign Ministry of the People's Republic of China, met NTC members in Benghazi.<ref>{{cite news|date=7 July 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|location=Beijing|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/07/us-china-libya-idUSTRE7660PX20110707|title=China deepens engagement with Libyan rebels|agency=Reuters}}</ref>
===8 July=== * Gaddafi issued another audio message broadcast through state television, exclaiming that NATO, the rebels and others who oppose his rule will be trampled "under the feet of the Libyan masses", and also repeated his threats of violence against NATO member states in Europe, saying that "Hundreds of Libyans will martyr in Europe. I told you it is eye for an eye and tooth for a tooth." Celebratory gunfire was heard in Tripoli following the broadcast.<ref>{{cite news|url =http://www.boston.com/news/world/middleeast/articles/2011/07/08/gadhafi_supporters_pray_and_rally_in_tripoli/|title = Shouting, Libya's Gadhafi Lashes Out at NATO|last= Schreck|first=Adam|agency= [[Associated Press]]|work=The Boston Globe|date = 8 July 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41960775|title = Gaddafi Threatens Europe as Rebels Renew Push|last1= Carey|first1=Nick|last2=Graff|first2=Peter |agency= [[Reuters]]|work=[[MSNBC]]|date = 9 July 2011}}</ref> * NATO head Rasmussen told the Associated Press that progress was being made, but that political progress would be needed as well because "there is no military solution to the conflict solely." * NATO launched at least four bombs targeted against pro-Gaddafi forces in the Western Mountains, some {{convert|3|km|abbr=off}} east of the village of [[Al-Qawalish]]. * Poland officially opened diplomatic ties with the NTC by installing its ambassador in Benghazi. * Five Libyan rebels were killed and 17 wounded during fighting in Misrata. * [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) issued a report accusing the Gaddafi government of laying "at least three minefields containing antipersonnel and antivehicle landmines" in areas of civilian traffic near al-Qawalish; in particular, two of the minefields were placed on a dirt road leading to an outskirts [[Public Scout and Girl Guide Movement|Boy Scout]] building located west of al-Qawalish. The HRW also cited rebels clearing up some 240 Brazilian-made T-AB-1 antipersonnel mines and 46 Chinese-made Type-72SP anti-vehicle mines from the sites since 6 July. Steve Goose, HRW arms director, said "The government's blatant disregard for the safety of its civilians is shameful", and that "Landmines are a weapon that will claim civilian limbs and lives for years to come".<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/07/08/libya-government-lays-more-mines-western-mountains|title = Libya: Government Lays More Mines in Western Mountains|publisher =[[Human Rights Watch]] |date = 8 July 2011}}</ref>
===9 July=== * Four boats with 1,401 migrants from Libya landed on the Italian island of [[Lampedusa]]. [[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata]] reported that [[Prime Minister of Italy|Italian Prime Minister]] [[Silvio Berlusconi]] cancelled his planned visit to the island. * A petro-chemical plant in Brega was destroyed by government troops, according to Ahmed Bani, refuting earlier allegations of rebel involvement in the destruction of the plant.<ref>{{cite news|url = http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7434884.html|title = Government Troops Destroy Petro-Chemical Plant in Brega: Spokesman for Libyan Rebels|work=People's Daily|date=9 July 2011|accessdate =10 July 2011}}</ref>
===10 July=== * One rebel was killed and thirty-two wounded during an attempted rebel advance upon Zliten. The casualties resulted from land mines laid by retreating troops in the neighbourhood of Suq al-Thulatha.<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i9jbd5tDAHv4Zfe_9ADI_jFShTYw?docId=CNG.a51e0ccb6c8ecb11fbc3a0a97df80911.361|title = Libya Rebels Take Casualties in Zliten Advance|agency = [[Agence France-Presse]] |work=[[Google News]]|date = 10 July 2011|location=Benghazi|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> * Pro-Gaddafi forces launched a counter-attack on al-Qawalish with the launching of half a dozen Grad rockets into the hamlet. Rebels replied with anti-tank fire.<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ieYX5052zrd_z8ZJMQxuNk4isojg?docId=CNG.a51e0ccb6c8ecb11fbc3a0a97df80911.911|title = Kadhafi Forces Counterattack Southwest of Tripoli|agency = [[Agence France-Presse]] |work=[[Google News]] |date = 10 July 2011}}</ref> * Egypt ended its unrestricted immigration policy for Libyan nationals traversing the border or airspace between the two countries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-10-2011-1442|date=10 July 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|work=Al Jazeera|title=Sun, 10 Jul 2011, 12:42}}</ref>
===11 July=== * Israeli television channel [[Arutz Sheva]] reported that Gaddafi was bracing for an assault by rebel fighters who had broken out in the Nusafa Mountain region. According to its report, Gaddafi had armed huge numbers of civilians in strategic towns overlooking Tripoli and planned to remain firmly ensconced.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/145602|title=Qadaffi Bracing for Rebel Offensive |work= [[Arutz Sheva]]|last= Queenann|first=Gavriel|date=11 July 2011|accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref>
===12 July=== * After contacting Gaddafi, Paris officials stated that Gaddafi is "prepared to leave".<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/07/12/gaddafi-ready-to-go-french-foreign-minister-alain-juppe-_n_895405.html|title = Gaddafi Is 'Ready To Go,' Says French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe| work = [[The Huffington Post]] |date = 12 July 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|location=Paris|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> * The [[National Assembly of France|French National Assembly]] voted overwhelmingly for further funding of NATO operations in Libya, with 482 deputies voting in favour and 27 against. The vote, while required, was a formality, according to [[Al Jazeera]]. * An airstrip laid out along a stretch of highway near Rhebat in the Nafusa Mountains was opened by a senior NTC minister, allowing an air connection via a small private company, [[Air Libya]], between Benghazi and the Amazigh rebels.<ref>{{cite news|date=12 July 2011|url=http://english.libya.tv/?p=7370|title=NTC Minister Opens Western Nafusa Mountains Air Link|work=[[Libya TV]]|accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref>
===13 July=== * The HWR criticized rebel treatment of civilian populations in the towns of al-Awaniya, Rayayinah, Zawiyat al-Bagul and [[al-Qawalish]]. Fred Abrahams, a special advisor for the HRW's program office, stated that "We documented fairly widespread looting of homes and shops, the burning of some homes of suspected Gaddafi supporters and – most disturbingly – the vandalisation of three medical clinics [and] local small hospitals, including the theft of some of the medical equipment." Rebel spokesman [[Mahmoud Jibril]] denied the allegations of civilian abuse, but a rebel commander in the Nafusa Mountains admitted some abuses had taken place, going on to say such attacks violated orders and some of those responsible had been punished.<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14135530|title = Libyan Rebels Abused Civilians: Human Rights Watch|work=BBC News |date = 13 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/07/13/libya-opposition-forces-should-protect-civilians-and-hospitals|title = Libya: Opposition Forces Should Protect Civilians and Hospitals|publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]]|date = 13 July 2011}}</ref> * Pro-Gaddafi forces launched a counter-attack on towns in [[Jabal al Gharbi District]], causing the rebels to retreat from al-Qawalish.<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/13/libya-qawalish-control-idUSLDE76C0YF20110713|title = Gaddafi Forces Retake Village South of Tripoli|agency = [[Reuters]] |date = 13 July 2011|first=Peter|last=Graff}}</ref> By the evening, the rebels counter-attacked and after a five-hour battle they retook the village and chased loyalist forces to the outskirts of Asbi'a. During the fighting, two rebels were killed and 17 wounded.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/07/13/libya.war/index.html?section=cnn_latest|title=Libyan Rebels Looted and Beat Civilians, Rights Group Says|publisher=CNN|accessdate=25 January 2012|date=14 July 2011|location=Zintan}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=14 July 2011|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/world/8272643/libya-rebels-on-the-march|title=Libya Rebels on the March|work=NineMSN|accessdate=25 January 2012|agency=Agence France-Presse}}</ref>
=== 14 July === *Russia's special representative for Africa [[Mikhail Margelov]] reported that [[Baghdadi Mahmudi]] told Margelov of a plan to "cover [Tripoli] with missiles and blow it up" if Tripoli was seized by the rebels.<ref>{{cite news|last=Osborn|first=Andrew|date=14 July 2011|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8636883/Libya-Col-Gaddafi-has-suicide-plan-to-blow-up-Tripoli.html|title=Libya: Col Gaddafi Has 'Suicide Plan' To Blow Up Tripoli|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK|accessdate=5 September 2011}}</ref> *Opposition forces armed with both light and heavy weapons, including tanks, armoured personnel carriers and technicals attempted to retake Brega.<ref>{{cite news|date=14 July 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-14-2011-2335|title=Libya Live Blog: Thursday, July 14, 2011 – 20:35|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=5 September 2011}}</ref> * The [[Democratic Party (Libya)]] was founded in London.<ref>{{cite news|date=14 July 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|url=http://www.bsr-russia.com/en/international-relations/item/1775-young-libyans-form-democratic-party.html|title=Young Libyans form Democratic Party|first=John|last=Bonar|work=BSR Russia}}</ref>
=== 15 July === *Japan and the US formally recognized the NTC as sole legitimate representative of Libya.<ref name=Japan>{{cite news| url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-07/15/c_13988116.htm|publisher=Xinhua News Agency|date=15 July 2011|accessdate=5 September 2011|title=Libya Contact Group To Recognize NTC as Legitimate Authority: FM}}</ref> *The [[Libya Contact Group]] recognised the NTC as the only legitimate governing body of Libya at a meeting in Istanbul. They noted that the Gaddafi government no longer had any legitimate authority in Libya and they recommended that certain members of his family should go.<ref>{{cite news|date=15 July 2011|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFLDE76E0W120110715|title=Text – Excerpts from Libya Contact Group Chair's Statement|work=Reuters Africa|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=5 September 2011}}</ref> The Libya Contact Group includes over forty countries, the European Union, the African Union, the UN, the Arab League, the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] and the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]].<ref>{{cite news|date=17 July 2011|url=http://arabnews.com/opinion/editorial/article473528.ece|title=Editorial: End of the Road|work=Arab News|accessdate=5 September 2011}}</ref> *Gaddafi stated, in an audio message, that the recognition of the "so-called" NTC was insignificant and that the fight against the "colonial aggression" would continue. His speech was broadcast in front of thousands of supporters gathered on the main square in Zliten, around {{convert|150|km|abbr=off}} east of Tripoli and less than an hour drive from rebel-held Misrata.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/16030861|work = [[Sky News]] |date=15 July 2011|accessdate=5 September 2011|title=Nations Formally Support Libyan Opposition}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/07/15/libya.us.recognition/index.html|work= [[CNN]] |date= 16 July 2011|accessdate=5 September 2011|title=U.S. Recognizes Libyan 'Rebels' Authority}}</ref>
===Late July (16–31 July)===
=== 16 July === *The rebel forces fought Gaddafi forces on the outskirts of Brega, suffering heavy casualties. At least 12 rebels were killed and 178 wounded.<ref>{{cite news|date=16 July 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/07/201171610179115527.html|title=New Blasts Rock the Libyan Capital|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Graff|first=Peter|date=17 July 2011|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/07/16/uk-libya-idUKTRE76C1H420110716|title=Heavy Casualties Reported in Libya Fighting|work=Reuters UK|agency=Reuters|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref>
=== 18 July === *The NTC claimed rebels took much of Brega and pro-Gaddafi forces were in retreat towards [[Ra's Lanuf]]. Between 150 and 200 loyalist troops reportedly remained in the town as rebels attempted to both clear them out and dismantle land mines.<ref>{{cite news|date=18 July 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/07/2011718131010939797.html|title=Libya Rebels Claim Victory in Fight for Brega|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref> The government in Tripoli denied Brega had fallen, with spokesman [[Moussa Ibrahim]] telling a [[CNN]] reporter, "We will turn Brega into hell. We will not give Brega up, even if this causes the death of thousands of rebels and the destruction of the whole city."<ref>{{cite news|work= [[CNN]]|date=18 July 2011|accessdate=19 July 2011|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/07/18/libya.war/index.html?iref=allsearch|title=Libyan Government Vows To Hold Oil City Against Rebels|last= Watson|first=Ivan}}</ref>
=== 19 July === *The media reported that though the majority of Gaddafi's troops had retreated toward Ra's Lanuf, opposition fighters in Brega were still taking casualties from loyalist holdouts, landmines, and artillery directed against the western outskirts of the port city. An NTC spokesman admitted that it would likely take at least ten more days for the anti-Gaddafi forces to secure Brega and its environs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.talkradionews.com/news/2011/7/19/battle-for-brega-lingers-amid-push-for-diplomacy-in-libya.html|work=The Talk Radio News Service|date=19 July 2011|accessdate=19 July 2011| author = Bazinet, Kenneth|title=Battle for Brega Lingers Amid Push For Diplomacy In Libya}}</ref> Later in the evening, opposition commanders said they had withdrawn forces from Brega under artillery fire to aid in disarming minefields east of the city. They claimed to control about one-third of Brega, including the residential area of New Brega, but did not hold the port.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/07/201171922526752203.html|work = [[Al Jazeera]]|date=19 July 2011|accessdate=19 July 2011|title=Libyan Rebels Pushed Back from Brega}}</ref> *Al Jazeera reported that tens of thousands of Gaddafi's supporters rallied in [['Aziziya]], {{convert|40|km|abbr=off}} southwest of Tripoli. Waving the green flags and chanting "Only God, Muammar and Libya" the supporters gathered in the town main square.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-20-2011-0322|work = [[Al Jazeera]]|date=20 July 2011|accessdate=20 July 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Wednesday, 20 July 2011 – 02:22}}</ref>
=== 20 July === {{see also|Fezzan campaign}} *''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported the opening of a new front in southwestern Libya near the desert city of [[Sabha, Libya|Sabha]], where opposition fighters operating out of [[Kufra]] allegedly captured a small village to the south and were reportedly preparing to advance on Sabha itself.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424053111904233404576458154035344420.html|work=The Wall Street Journal |date=20 July 2011|title=Rebels Move Toward Gadhafi Stronghold|first=Charles|last=Levinson}}</ref> *Even as the rebel offensive toward Brega was hampered by shelling and booby traps, anti-Gaddafi forces advanced to within {{convert|1.5|km|abbr=off}} of Zliten, opposition sources said.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jul/20/libya-rebels-zlitan-brega|work=The Guardian |location=London |date=20 July 2011|accessdate=20 July 2011|title=Libyan Rebels Push Towards Zlitan| author = Stephen, Chris}}</ref> *NTC Defence Minister [[Jalal al-Digheily]] visited [[Nalut]] to tour the Nafusa Mountains front and tout the alliance between [[Arab people|Arab]] and [[Berber people|Amazigh]] fighters in the region.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=38225|work = [[The Jamestown Foundation]]|title=Special Commentary from Inside Western Libya|last = Flood|first=Derek Henry|date=25 July 2011|accessdate=6 August 2011}}</ref>
=== 21 July === *In heavy fighting near Zliten, the rebels reportedly captured a loyalist general of the Hamza Brigade, Gen. Abdul Nabih Zayed.<ref name="rules">{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/07/2011721232433682725.html?utm_content=automateplus&utm_campaign=Trial5&utm_source=SocialFlow&utm_term=tweets&utm_medium=MasterAccount|work= [[Al Jazeera]] |date=22 July 2011|accessdate=21 July 2011|title=Gaddafi Rules Out Talks with Libya Rebels}}</ref> *NTC Prime Minister [[Mahmoud Jibril]] said he had credible information that Gaddafi loyalists have rigged oil facilities in Brega to explode if the [[Libyan Army (1951–2011)|Libyan Army]] was forced to abandon the town. Opposition fighters continued to work to disarm mines and booby-traps planted in and around Brega.<ref name="rules"/> *Gaddafi ruled out talks with the opposition fighters seeking to end his forty-one-year-rule, but a spokesman from his government has not ruled out dialogue with the US. "There will be no talks between me and them until Judgment Day," Gaddafi told a crowd of thousands of his supporters in his home city of [[Sirte]] in a remotely delivered audio message.<ref name="rules"/> *The Libyan government said that NATO air strikes targeted civilian sites in Zliten. Foreign media were shown destroyed buildings and wounded civilians in the town.<ref name="rules"/>
=== 22 July === * A [[United States Department of State|US State Department]] spokesman said the US government was looking into allegations by rebels in western Libya that on 19 July, Algeria allowed a Libyan-flagged ship loaded with weapons to dock in the Algerian port of [[Djen Djen]], then shipped those weapons overland to Libya for use by Gaddafi's troops. The spokesman said that if true, this action would place Algeria in violation of UNSCR 1970 and UNSCR 1973, which forbid arms trafficking to the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.moroccoboard.com/news/5363|date=23 July 2011|accessdate=23 July 2011|title=Algeria May Have Violated UN Resolution by Providing Weapons to Libya, US State Dept.| work = [[MoroccoBoard News Service]]}}</ref> There was evidence that Qatar had been sending crates of ammunition along with humanitarian supplies, although Al Jazeera stated that they were "unable to find out if they were for the Qatari security forces to use or the rebels".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-22-2011-1150|date=22 July 2011|accessdate=24 July 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Friday, July 22, 2011  – 11:50 |work= [[Al Jazeera]]}}</ref> * It was reported that a [[mass grave]], believed to contain the remains of Gaddafi loyalists, had been discovered in the Nafusa Mountains, adding to concerns over the way the Libyan rebels treated captives and the civil population in territories under its control. The identity of the men, one of whom had been decapitated, remained unknown. Sukant Chandan, a spokesman for the [[British Civilians For Peace in Libya]] movement declared to [[RT (TV Network)|RT]]:. {{cquote|Crimes committed by the rebels are being swept under the carpet to support NATO's cause in the region. Fundamentally, there has been a problem in the way the NATO nations and their media have portrayed these so-called rebels. These rebels have been conducting mass [[lynching|lynches]] of black people throughout the first several weeks and months of this crisis. The question has been raised several times at press conferences, but has not been answered. The media does not reflect these issues as 'it does not fit the narrative'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rt.com/news/mutilated-corpses-libya-rights/print/|date=22 July 2011|accessdate=25 July 2011|title=Mutilated Pro-Gaddafi Soldiers Found Dead in Rebel-Controlled Area – Report|work= [[RT (TV network)|RT]]}}</ref>}}
=== 23 July === * Loyalist forces recaptured [[Qatrun]] in the southern [[Libyan Desert]], forcing Toubou tribesmen allied with the [[National Liberation Army (Libya)|National Liberation Army]] (NLA) to retreat south of the town.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Jul-23/Libya-rebels-report-loss-of-Qatrun.ashx#axzz1SwMHYYAg|title=Libya Rebels Report Loss of Qatrun|work=[[Daily Star (Lebanon)|Daily Star]]|accessdate=25 January 2012|date=23 July 2011|location=Benghazi|agency=Agence France-Presse}}</ref> * Several thousand people gathered in the centre of Sirte, Gaddafi's hometown, during another of a series of pro-Gaddafi rallies in the past weeks to show support to Gaddafi.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14262131|date=23 July 2011|accessdate=25 July 2011|author= Reynolds, James|title=Libya: Show of Support for Gaddafi in Sirte|work=BBC News}}</ref>
=== 24 July === * Germany began offering loans of up to $144 million to the NTC to help with humanitarian needs and rebuilding. [[Guido Westerwelle]] announced that his country is giving out loans, because Gaddafi's frozen assets cannot be released at the time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Germany-Offers-Loans-to-Libyan-Rebels-126080443.html|date=24 July 2011|accessdate=25 July 201|title=Germany Offers Loans to Libyan Rebels|work= [[VOA News]]}}</ref> * NATO war planes destroyed two command and control nodes, two surface-to-air missile launchers, and one anti-aircraft gun in Tripoli; while rebels also repulsed a counter-attack, by loyalist forces in the southwest.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/rebels-repulse-attack-by-gaddafi-forces-20110725-1hvuk.html|date=25 July 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|title=Rebels Repulse Attack by Gaddafi Forces|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|agency=Agence France-Presse}}</ref> *It was reported that the Libyan opposition forces had repelled an offensive by government troops in the town of [[Qwalish]]. Sunday's attack was aimed at recapturing the strategic desert town, southwest Tripoli. Witnesses said dozens of civilians were sent to the area just before the attack. Opposition fighters seized control of the region earlier this month.<ref>{{cite news|date=25 July 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-25-2011-0007|title=Libya Live Blogs: Monday, July 25, 2011 – 00:07|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=17 August 2011}}</ref>
=== 25 July === * Reuters reported that a group of Libyan diplomats and staff stormed the Libyan embassy in [[Sofia]], Bulgaria, smashing statues and portraits of Gaddafi and declaring the embassy under the control of the opposition forces. Footage from private Bulgarian television station, [[bTV (Bulgaria)|bTV]], showed several opposition supporters taking down the Libyan flag and smashing a bust of Gaddafi to pieces in the embassy's yard. The group detained the ''charge d'affairs'' of the embassy and his secretary, who declined to denounce the Libyan leader. The two were later allowed to leave, Reuters said, citing bTV.<ref>{{cite news|date=25 July 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/07/25/libya-embassy-in-bulgaria_n_908534.html|title=Libya Embassy In Bulgaria Flies Rebel Flag|work=Huffington Post|agency=Associated Press|location=Sofia}}</ref>
=== 26 July === * The pro-Gaddafi government would not agree to negotiations while NATO airstrikes are ongoing, said [[Baghdadi Mahmudi]], prime minister of the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, after meeting with a UN envoy. He also said that Gaddafi could not be asked to leave power or quit Libya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-26-2011-2022|date=26 July 2011|accessdate=26 July 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Tuesday, July 26, 2011 – 19:22|work= [[Al Jazeera]]}}</ref> * CNN reported that NATO warplanes had struck a health clinic, a food-storage complex and a military base in Zliten, allegedly killing at least 11 civilians. The video report also shows ruins of a mosque and school located on the outskirts of the city which were destroyed by air strikes. NATO later issued a statement where they rejected claims that they have hit non-military targets near the coastal city, claiming instead to have hit a command and control node and a vehicle storage facility.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/07/25/libya.fighting/index.html|date=26 July 2011|accessdate=26 July 2011|author1=Watson, Ivan |author2=Karadsheh, Jomana |title=Libya's Zlitan Increasingly in Rebel, NATO Sights|work = [[CNN]]}}</ref>
=== 27 July === * The ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported several cases of officials in Gaddafi's government "manicuring the facts". One example was a house in Zliten that government officials claimed was bombed by NATO warplanes and had no military use. However, a man was hastily trying to hide a soldier's green helmet and army uniforms there. Another building was claimed by officials to have been used by a Turkish road construction company but there was graffiti on the walls that appeared to have been written by Libyan soldiers using it as a military base. One night at Triploli's port, a Gaddafi government minder pointed out a ship in flames in the dark and claimed it was a private yacht. The next morning, in the light of day, it was clear the burning vessel was a frigate.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peel|first=Michael|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/9a6d418a-b85a-11e0-8d23-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1T|title=Libyan Propaganda War Deals Some Clumsy Shots|work=Financial Times|date=27 July 2011|accessdate=1 August 2011}}{{registration required|date=January 2012}}</ref>
=== 28 July === *Opposition forces in the Nafusa Mountains began an assault on Gaddafi forces in the towns of al-Jawsh and Ghazaya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/07/20117287598328864.html|date=28 July 2011|accessdate=28 July 2011 |title= Fighters Launch Assault in Libya's West|work = [[Al Jazeera]]}}</ref> They announced the capture of Ghazaya several hours later.<ref>{{cite news|title=Libya Rebels 'Capture Key Supply Route Town of Ghazaya'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14321751|accessdate=28 July 2011|work=BBC News|date=28 July 2011}}</ref> *General [[Abdul Fatah Younis]], top commander of the rebel forces, was arrested as some on the NTC questioned his loyalty.<ref>{{cite news|title=Libya Opposition Arrests Senior Leader|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/07/2011728144624965299.html|accessdate=28 July 2011|work = [[Al Jazeera]] |date=28 July 2011}}</ref> His assassination, allegedly ''en route'' to detention in Benghazi, was later announced by the NTC. A man was arrested in connection with the murder.<ref>{{cite news|title=Libya Live Blog|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-29-2011-0012|accessdate=28 July 2011|work= [[Al Jazeera]] |date=28 July 2011}}</ref>
=== 29 July === *The body of Younis, shot and burned before being dumped outside Benghazi, was recovered and a funeral was held.<ref name="funeral">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jul/29/abdel-fatah-younis-death-libya|work=The Guardian |location=London |date=29 July 2011|title=Abdel Fatah Younis Assassination Creates Division Among Libya Rebels|last= Stephen|first=Chris |accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref> *[[Suleiman Mahmoud]] was named to succeed Younis as the rebels' top commander.<ref name=fellowrebels>{{cite news|date=29 July 2011|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-07-29-libya-rebel-chief-slain_n.htm|title=Officer accuses fellow rebels in Libya killing|work=USA Today|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> *In protest over Younis's death and the NTC's handling of the incident, the local committee and military commander in Misrata declared they would ignore orders from Benghazi.<ref name="funeral"/> *Finance Minister [[Ali Tarhouni]], a prominent member of the NTC, said the suspect arrested in connection with the Younis's assassination was a rebel militia leader whom the NTC had dispatched to arrest Younis and bring him back to Benghazi. Tarhouni said that the militia commander, whose name was not made public, claimed he was unable to stop his subordinates from shooting Younis and two of his aides instead of escorting them back to Benghazi as ordered.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/29/us-libya-younes-perpetrator-idUSTRE76S62U20110729| agency = [[Reuters]]|date=29 July 2011|accessdate=29 July 2011|title=Rebels Killed Libya's Younes: Rebel Minister}}</ref> This account generally conformed to the claims of an eyewitness who made separate allegations earlier in the day, before Tarhouni spoke, blaming the attacks on members of the 17 February Martyrs' Brigade who allegedly claimed that Younis had their father killed several years earlier.<ref name=fellowrebels/>
=== 30 July === *Early in the morning, NATO bombed three satellite dishes in Tripoli in an attempt to put state television off the air, but the channel continued to broadcast. NATO at first released a press video to journalists titled "NATO Silences Gaddafi's Terror Broadcasts" but later changed that to "NATO Strikes Libyan State TV Satellite Facility".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-30-2011-1104|work = [[Al Jazeera]] |date=30 July 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Saturday, July 30, 2011 – 11:04|accessdate=30 July 2011}}</ref> *According to Khaled Basilia, the director of al-Jamahiriya television's English-language service, the airstrikes on the state broadcasters facilities killed three journalist and wounded another 15. He termed the air strike "an act of international terrorism" and says that it violated the UN resolutions under which NATO was acting. "We are not a military target, we are not commanders in the army and we do not pose threat to civilians," he said. He also demanded full protection from the international community. NATO said it was acting to "protect civilians" by hitting the site.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-30-2011-1604| work = [[Al Jazeera]]|date=30 July 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Saturday, July 30, 2011 – 16:04|accessdate=30 July 2011}}</ref> *Libyan rebels captured the town of Takhut in the Western Mountains near the Wazin border crossing after previously taking Ghezaya.<ref>Staff (30 July 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-30-2011-1654 "''Libya Live Blog'': Saturday, 30 July 2011 – 16:54]. [[Al Jazeera]].
