=== 31 July === *Fighters loyal to the NTC raided a Benghazi neighborhood and traded gunfire with members of a militia group that refused to surrender their arms in compliance with the NTC's edict that all militias must disband. The NTC forces reportedly stormed a license plate factory during the early-morning clashes and arrested close to 50 militiamen. At a news conference, officials claimed the fighters constituted a [[fifth column]] of Gaddafi loyalists masquerading as rebels, but journalists were unable to independently confirm these assertions. Three NTC soldiers were killed and eight injured, while the rogue militia suffered four dead and twelve wounded, according to the NTC.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/01/world/africa/01libya.html?_r=1&pagewanted=1| author = Kirkpatrick, David |work=The New York Times|date=31 July 2011|accessdate=1 August 2011|title=Clash in Benghazi Exposes Cracks in Libyan Rebel Ranks}}</ref> *Rebels reportedly captured Al-Josh in the Western Mountains. However, loyalist forces did not retreat far from the city.<ref>Staff (31 July 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-jul-31-2011-1641 "''Libya Live Blog'': Sunday, 31 July 2011 – 16:41]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 17 August 2011.</ref> Hours later, the village was retaken by loyalist forces and the rebels were driven out.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-1-2011-1324|work=Al Jazeera |date=1 August 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Monday, August 1, 2011 – 13:24|accessdate=1 August 2011}}</ref> *Reuters reported that an estimated 5,000 residents of Ghezaya, supporters of Gaddafi, were transported to Tripoli during the rebels' advance against the town before they have seized it, leaving behind a ghost town. news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-2-2011-1548|work = [[Al Jazeera]]| title= ''Libya Live Blog'': Tuesday, August 2, 2011  – 13:48 | date = 2 August 2011 | accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> While in the town's centre, the rebels waited for an approval of Zliten's Fowater tribe to take control of the town, but they did not immediately agree.<ref>{{cite news| url = [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-4-2011-1824 "''Libya Live Blog'': 4 August 2011 – 15:24"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. ===6 August=== * The NTC announced a new program as part of a temporary financial mechanism to distribute 14 million [[Libyan dinar]]s "for a [[Sadaqah|Family Support Programme]] to be distributed directly to families throughout the Nafusa Mountains" during [[Ramadan]]. In a statement, it said working people in the mountains had not been paid wages since January 2011, and the payments would help "kick-start the economy".<ref>{{cite web|author = Press release |url=http://shabablibya.org/news/ntctfm-press-release-saturday-august-6-2011|title = NTC/TFM Press Release Saturday August 6, 2011 | publisher = [[National Transitional Council]]|work=Shabab Libya| date=6 August 2011|accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| work= [[Al Jazeera]]|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-6-2011-1444|date=6 August 2011|accessdate=1 September 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Saturday, 6 August 2011 – 12:44}}</ref> * Opposition forces captured [[Bir al-Ghanem]] in western Libya in their advance toward [[Zawiya, Libya|Zawiya]]. ===7 August=== *Pro-Gaddafi forces attempted to retake Bir al-Ghanam. NATO use the Thuraya telephones to give crusaders the coordinates of some locations to be bombed, which has caused the deaths of a large number of civilians." Reuters noted the phones are Emirati in origin and are also frequently used by foreign journalists in Libya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/11/us-libya-satphones-threat-idUSTRE77A3CL20110811|agency = [[Reuters]] |date=11 August 2011|accessdate=28 August 2011|title=Libya Bans Unauthorised Thurayas, To Treat Users as Spies}}</ref> *The [[Government of the United Arab Emirates|Emirati government]] turned over a captured [[Libyan Air Force (1951–2011)|Libyan Air Force]] [[Ilyushin Il-76]] transport plane to the NTC in Benghazi, who welcomed it as the [[Free Libyan Air Force]]'s "first cargo plane" and said it would be "used to transport humanitarian aid from abroad to Libya".<ref>{{cite news| title=Cargo Plane Handed Over to Libya Rebels|url=http://www.arabstoday.net/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=22455:cargo-plane-handed-over-to-libya-rebels&catid=117:also-in-the-news| agency = [[Agence France-Presse]] |work=Arabs Today| date = 11 August 2011|accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> *Rebels in western Libya claimed they had taken Nasr and [[Bir Shuaib]], putting them less than {{convert|25|km|abbr=off}} from Zawiya,<ref name=key>{{cite news| url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-08-11-libya-rebels_n.htm| agency = [[Associated Press]]|work=USA Today|date=12 August 2011|accessdate=2 September 2011|title=Libyan Rebels Claim Victory in Key Oil Terminal}}</ref> but they did not allow journalists all the way to the front to independently confirm the report. The signs of recent NATO airstrikes in [[Shalghouda]], aiding the fighters' advance, were observed by Western reporters.<ref name="porgythu"/> *An [[National Liberation Army (Libya)|NLA]] spokesman near Brega said most civilians and loyalist soldiers had fled from the port city.<ref name="porgythu"/> Late in the day, rebel forces claimed to have "liberated" Brega.<ref name="key"/> Al Jazeera reported that while the eastern, residential parts of Brega seemed to be under rebel control, fighting was still taking place in the south of the city, and the western part remained in pro-Gaddafi hands.<ref>{{cite news|date=11 August 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-11-2011-2056|title=Libya Live Blog: Thursday, August 11, 2011 – 18:56|agency=[[Reuters]]|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> At least eight rebel soldiers were killed and about twenty-five more were injured during the fighting. An injured soldier told Al Jazeera, "Brega has been liberated on 11 August 2011."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-12-2011-0649|work = [[Al Jazeera]]|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Friday, August 12, 2011 – 03:49|accessdate=28 August 2011|date= 12 August 2011}}</ref> *Tunisian troops were conducting regular checks at gas stations in southern Tunisia and policing the amount of gasoline or diesel fuel allotted per customer, according to a [[Ministry of Defence (Tunisia)|Tunisian Ministry of Defense]] spokesman, who said the new measures were intended to prevent fuel smuggling into Libya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://arabnews.com/middleeast/article487607.ece|agency = [[Reuters]]|work=Arab News |title=Libya Fighters Take Casualties in Fight for Brega|date=12 August 2011|accessdate=28 August 2011| author = Birsel, Robert}}</ref>
===12 August=== {{see also|Battle of Tawergha}} *A [[prisoner of war]] claiming to be an [[intelligence officer]] said Gaddafi was still "very strong" and enjoyed the backing of about seventy percent of Tripoli residents.<ref>{{cite news |last= Georgy |first= Michael |date= 12 August 2011 |url= http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE77B0MM20110812?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title= Captured Intel Officer Says Gaddafi Still Strong |work= Reuters Africa |agency= Reuters |accessdate= 16 August 2011}}</ref> *France's aircraft carrier [[French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle (R91)|''Charles de Gaulle'' (R91)]], returned to the port of [[Toulon]] for maintenance after more than four months of continuous operations off the Libyan coast. [[President of France|French President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] gave a speech to forces aboard the ''Charles de Gaulle'', reaffirming France's commitment to continue the aerial bombardment of Libya "until the end of the mission".<ref>[http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_18667927]. ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]''.</ref> *The [[Moscow Kremlin|Russian government]] moved to comply with UN Security Council Resolution 1973 by strengthening [[economic sanctions]] against the Gaddafi government, freezing the assets of Gaddafi and his inner circle inside Russia and banning the use of Russian airspace by Libyan aircraft or any aircraft on a non-humanitarian mission to Libya.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.english.rfi.fr/africa/20110812-russia-signs-libya-sanctions-rebels-advance|work= [[Radio France Internationale]] |title=Russia Signs Libya Sanctions as Rebels Advance|date= 12 August 2011|accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref> *NTC forces pushing southeast out of Misrata took control of [[Tawergha]], though they continued to face lingering resistance in the old quarter of the city. An Al Jazeera correspondent reported that soldiers were conducting house-to-house sweeps in an effort to locate and arrest loyalist snipers in the city.<ref name="tawurgha">{{cite news | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/08/201181215510690602.html| work= [[Al Jazeera]] |date=13 August 2011|accessdate=22 August 2011|title=Libya Rebels Eye Brega Oil Installations}}</ref>
===13 August=== {{see also|Battle of Gharyan|Second Battle of Zawiya}} *Opposition fighters briefly claimed they had taken control of [[Gharyan]], but then later told the Associated Press that fighting there was renewed when loyalist forces pushed from the garrison city at the foot of the Nafusa Mountains returned with reinforcements. One anti-Gaddafi volunteer said many residents of Gharyan had risen up to join the fight against Gaddafi's soldiers. However, no journalists were allowed to the front, and these claims could not be confirmed.<ref name="foxap">{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/08/13/libyan-rebels-claim-capture-gateway-to-tripoli/| agency= [[Associated Press]]|publisher=Fox News |date= 13 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title= Heavy Clashes as Libyan Rebels Enter Strategic City}}</ref><ref name="voan">{{cite news | url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Fresh-Clashes-in-Western-Libya--127652433.html|work= [[Voice of America]] |date= 13 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title= Libyan Forces, Rebels, Clash in Two Regions}}</ref> Late in the day, a rebel official said anti-Gaddafi forces had captured two fuel tankers, as well as weapons, vehicles, and ammunition, and controlled ninety-five percent of the city, with a loyalist brigade pinned down in one of Gharyan's numerous military bases.<ref name="cnn-war">{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/08/13/libya.war/|date= 13 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011| work = [[CNN]] |title= Rebels Say They Are Gaining Ground in Libya; Government Disputes Claim}}</ref> *A spokesman for rebel forces pushing toward Zawiya said fighters were surrounding the city and had made contact with its residents, who signaled readiness to join the fight as they approached.<ref name="foxap"/> A Reuters producer and his crew reported the coastal highway was blocked at Zawiya and they could hear the sound of gunfire on the city's outskirts.<ref>{{cite news| author = Lowe, Christian | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/13/us-libya-idUSTRE77A2Y920110813|agency = [[Reuters]] |date=13 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title = Rebels, Gaddafi Forces Clash Near Tunisia: Sources}}</ref> Al Jazeera English reported that fighting was taking place inside the city,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-13-2011-1851|work = [[Al Jazeera]]|date= 13 August 2011 | accessdate=2 September 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'': Saturday, 13 August 2011 – 16:51}}</ref> and an Associated Press reporter on the scene reported residents of the city were rushing into the streets by the hundreds to greet the rebels as they entered Zawiya. One force reportedly advanced to a bridge on the southwestern edge of the city, while another group punched through into the city centre.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/article/Heavy-clashes-as-Libyan-rebels-enter-Zawiya-1882431.php| author = Laub, Karin | agency = [[Associated Press]]|work=[[San Antonio Express-News]]| title= Libyan Rebels Try To Cut Routes to Tripoli |date= 14 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011}}</ref> By nightfall, the rebels reportedly occupied the city centre but did not yet have full control, with fighting raging back and forth across the arterial highway running through the city. A Gaddafi government spokesman denied rebels had taken the city, calling it a "suicide mission" and saying they had been "stopped easily".<ref name="whitecaps">{{cite news |author1=Veal, Martin |author2=Ryan, Missy |url= http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Gaddafi+forces+rebels+fight+over+Zawiyah/5252414/story.html |agency= [[Reuters]] |work= Vancouver Sun |location= Canada |title= Gaddafi Forces, Rebels Fight Over Zawiyah |date= 13 August 2011 |accessdate= 20 August 2011}}</ref> *A colonel held in Misrata as a POW by the rebels said Gaddafi used mercenaries to force the regular army to fight and keep them from deserting. He said that at the time he was captured roughly two months prior, divisions were forming between the army and the mercenaries. "I think it will soon collapse," he claimed of the loyalist fighting force.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-13-2011-1520| work = [[Al Jazeera]] |date= 13 August 2011|accessdate=2 September 2011|title=''Libya Live Blog'':Saturday, 13 August 2011 – 13:20}}</ref> *A NATO airstrike against loyalist positions in Brega destroyed two armored vehicles and killed six Libyan Army servicemen.<ref name="georgy13">{{cite news|url= http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE77C03S20110813?sp=true|author = Georgy, Michael| work=Reuters Africa|agency = [[Reuters]] |date= 13 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title=Libyan Rebels Advance on Zawiyah, Battle in Brega}}</ref> *Rebel forces moved to capture the [[Ras Ajdir]] border crossing with Tunisia, clashing with loyalist troops defending the crossing.<ref name="whitecaps"/> *An NTC spokesman claimed Tawergha was secured and rebels had taken up new positions south of the city, capturing a bridge on the highway to Sirte.<ref name="cnn-war"/> An officer involved in the successful offensive said that despite the loss of twelve anti-Gaddafi fighters, "Our martyrs can rest easy in their graves, and the children can sleep easy in their beds."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14519304|work=BBC News |title = Libya Conflict: Zawiya Claims Denied by Moussa Ibrahim |date= 13 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011}}</ref>
===14 August=== *Reuters reported that rebels held the city centre of Zawiya, though rebel commanders claimed loyalist snipers remained in the city and a Reuters correspondent inside the city said occasional gunfire could be heard.<ref name="jdir">{{cite news| author = George, Michael | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/14/us-libya-idUSTRE77A2Y920110814| agency = [[Reuters]] |date= 14 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title= Libyan Rebels Fly Flag Over Key Town Near Tripoli}}</ref> Al Jazeera reported the city centre remained contested, though it quoted rebels as saying that they controlled seventy percent of Zawiya.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/08/2011813913965166.html|work= [[Al Jazeera]]|date= 15 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title = Gaddafi Defiant as Rebels Claim Gains in West}}</ref> A colonel with the Nafusi military command claimed in an interview with Al Jazeera that although fighting continued "as opposition forces are pushing pro-Gaddafi forces out", Zawiya was effectively under their control.<ref name="colonel">{{cite news| url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-14-2011-2236|work = [[Al Jazeera]] |date= 14 August 2011|accessdate=2 September 2011|title= ''Libya Live Blog'': Sunday, 14 August 2011 – 20:36}}</ref> *Rebels claimed they had taken [[Sorman]], just west of Zawiya, but this report could not be immediately corroborated.<ref name="colonel"/> A spokesman for opposition forces said ten rebels were killed and thirty-four were injured, but added that the city was secured and fighting had stopped.<ref>{{cite news| author = Lowe, Christian | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFLDE77D06920110814| work=Reuters Africa|agency = [[Reuters]] |date=14 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title=Rebels Say Capture Another Town West of Tripoli}}</ref> *Fighting reportedly continued in Gharyan, according to a rebel commander, though he said the city was controlled by the Libyan opposition.<ref name="colonel"/> *Two Libyans crossing into Tunisia claimed they witnessed clashes in [[Sabratha]], west of Sorman.<ref name="jdir"/> *Reuters investigated eyewitness accounts of clashes at the Ras Ajdir border crossing from the previous evening and found loyalist Libyan customs and immigration officials operating normally, though occasional gunshots could be heard on the Libyan side of the border.<ref name="jdir"/> *A rebel colonel in the Nafusa Mountains told Al Jazeera that [[Ajaylat]] had been secured by anti-Gaddafi forces.<ref name="colonel"/>
===15 August=== *Fighting continued in Zawiya, with rebels still unable to reach Martyrs' Square in the city's centre because of sniper fire and shelling.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-15-2011-1725| work = [[Al Jazeera]] |title= ''Libya Live Blog'': Monday, August 15, 2011  – 15:25 | format = Video (00:02:15; requires [[Adobe Flash]]) | date=15 August 2011| accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> They told Al Jazeera they had arrested fifteen "mercenaries" and were attempting to clear the remaining pro-Gaddafi forces from the city.<ref name="wrup">{{cite news | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/08/2011815152319924422.html|work = [[Al Jazeera]]|title=Libyan Rebels Push To Isolate Tripoli|date= 16 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011}}</ref> *Opposition forces said they had taken Gharyan and were in "full control" of the garrison city.<ref name="wrup"/><ref name="rfe-15">{{cite news| url=http://www.rferl.org/content/qaddafi_calls_on_prepare_for_battle_rebels_advance/24296923.html| work = [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|date=15 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title=Qaddafi Defiant as Libyan Rebels Enter Key Towns Near Tripoli}}</ref> *Negotiations between NTC and loyalist representatives reportedly took place in Tunisia. According to some reports, foreign officials were also present, including former Jordanian Foreign Minister [[Abdul Ilah Khatib]] in his capacity as the UN's special envoy to Libya.<ref name="wrup"/> One report suggested a representative from the [[Government of Venezuela|Venezuelan government]], a strong ally of Tripoli, was in attendance.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-aug-15-2011-1640| work = [[Al Jazeera]] |title= ''Libya Live Blog'': Monday, August 15, 2011  – 14:40 |date= 15 August 2011|accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> Other reports said Qatari and South African aircraft were at [[Djerba]], the Tunisian island where negotiations between the factions had historically been held. NTC Vice Chairman [[Abdul Hafiz Ghoga]] categorically denied his government was negotiating with the Gaddafi government, while the UN declined to confirm or deny whether Khatib was mediating negotiations.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/fighting-rages-libya-amid-parley-reports-0| work = [[Radio Netherlands]]|date=15 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title=Fighting Rages in Libya as Talks Reports Denied}}</ref> *Interior Minister [[Nasr al-Mabrouk Abdullah]] apparently defected from the Gaddafi government, flying to [[Cairo]], Egypt, with his family.<ref name="rfe-15"/> *Opposition fighters in Sabratha said they were negotiating the surrender of loyalist holdouts in the coastal town.<ref name="local">{{cite news| author = Borger, Julian; Stephen, Chris; [[Richard Norton-Taylor|Norton-Taylor, Richard]] | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/aug/15/muammar-gaddafi-losing-grasp-libya|work=The Guardian |location=London |date=15 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011|title = Libya Shows Signs of Slipping from Muammar Gaddafi's Grasp}}</ref> *The NTC issued a statement urging people in areas still under Gaddafi's control to organise into local committees in preparation for the fall of the government.<ref name="local"/> *Gaddafi loyalists in Sirte, in an apparent attempt at revenge for recent battlefield defeats, fired a [[Scud]] missile towards rebel-held territory near [[Ajdabiya]], though it landed harmlessly in the desert. A Western official said, "That it didn't hit anything or kill anyone is not the point. It's a weapon of mass destruction that Colonel Gaddafi is willing to train on his own people."<ref>{{cite news|author1=McElroy, Damien |author2=Spencer, Richard | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8703041/Col-Gaddafi-fires-scud-missile-at-rebel-territory-as-Nato-braces-itself-for-final-violent-showdown.html|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London | date=15 August 2011| accessdate=20 August 2011| title=Col Gaddafi Fires Scud Missile at Rebel Territory as Nato Braces Itself for Final Violent Showdown}}</ref> *Rebels in the Nafusa Mountains claimed to have finally taken Teji, though the report was not verified.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14523802|work=BBC News |title=Libya Conflict: Rebels Fight for Key Towns Near Tripoli|date=15 August 2011|accessdate=20 August 2011}}</ref> *Opposition forces announced that Tripoli was cut off from supplies and effectively besieged, with routes through the cities of Zawiya and Gharyan under rebel control, and supply routes from Tunisia and the south of Libya into Tripoli blocked.<ref>{{cite news|last=Georgy|first=Michael|date=15 August 2011|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/15/us-libya-idUSTRE77A2Y920110815|title=Rebels Say Tripoli Encircled; Gaddafi Defiant|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref>
